phrase.item: Once in a town there lived a king.
He was a very smart and kind king.
He grew older, but did not have any sons.
However, he had two daughters.
He had a vizier who was a doctor, who made a medicine from flowers and herbs and gave it to him and his wife.
After some time he had a son.
The king and his wife were very happy.
They celebrated for seven nights and days.
He gave his son the name of Kingir.
His son grew up and [went] to a teacher to study.
He gained a lot of knowladge.
The king loved his son very much.
He didn't want him to go far from his side.
One day he [Kingir] asked his father, "Oh father, in the world is it good to eat and drink or to travel the world?"
The king thought for a while and then said, "To eat and to drink is good."
If he had said traveling the world was good, his son would have leave him.
The king was completely against him leaving.
After this story, some time passed and [one day] the king told to his wife: "Let's arrange Kingir's marriage".
They went to propose a beautiful girl, who was the vizier's daughter.
At that moment Kingir was walking with his friends in the garden.
He asked his friends as well whether it is good to travel the world or to eat and drink.
His friends replied, "Stupid, it's good to travel the world."
"Your father tricked you."
"Because [he didn't want] you to go away from him."
Kingir came home and told his parents, "Prepare provisions for me, because I will go on a journey tomorrow."
His parents kept begging him not to go far away from them, but Kingir did not capitulate.
[The next day] in the morning, he made his horse ready, tied his provisions to it and left.
The king and his wife ran after him and kept telling not to leave, but he didn't capitulate.
The king went back and told the girl who was engaged to his son to follow him [Kingir],
because when he remembered his wedding he would return.
Kingir walked a lot and once he turned back he saw that a lady was running after him.
He stayed in place.
The lady reached him.
She was as yellow as [a yellow powder].
Kingir asked her, "What happened to you?"
"Why is your face so yellow?"
The girl replied, "Because of you."
After saying that she fell down where she was and died.
Kingir was surprised; "what should I do [here] in the steppe?" he thought for a while.
Then he left again.
[After] seven days and nights he got close to a city and saw a sycamore at the edge of a pond.
There was a ladder by that sycamore.
He tied his horse by the pond and climbed the ladder.
Then he saw there was a small house made of wood on top of the sycamore.
Inside the house there was a cradle and a bed.
Since Kingir hadn't for seven days and nights he lay down and fall asleep right away.
This small house which was on the branch of the sycamore was made for the king of the town.
The king of that town liked hunting very much.
Whenever he went hunting, upon coming back he stayed for one week in that small house.
When Kingir came to that house the king had gone hunting.
The king's palace was close to the sycamore.
The king of this town had a beautiful daughter whose face was like the sun and moon.
The princess's servants used to come to take water from the pond.
When the girl's servants came to the pool to get water, they saw their faces in the water.
They said, "We are also beautful like the king's daughter".
"If so then why are we serving her?"
They hit their vases on the stone and they broke.
Luʈ is a vase made of a specific kind of clay.
They came and told to the king's daughter, "Why are you being so vain about your looks, we are also beautiful like you."
There was a lady called Bibi among the servants, she was very smart and said, "I am going to bring water."
She took the vase and left. She stole a mirror from king's daughter and hid it inside her stocking.
When she was about to take water from the pool, she saw her face in the water.
Then she took the mirror and looked at [herself]; it didn't look like the face she'd seen in the water at all.
She looked up and saw that inside the house on the sycamore a handsome boy was sleeping.
The servant climbed up the ladder and [saw] that a handsome boy was sleeping there; she tried to wake him up but couldn't.
She stayed next to him until evening and he didn't wake up because he was sleeping deeply.
After sunset the servant took water and went to the king's daughter.
The king's daughter said, "Why did you come so late?"
The servant said, "I just cleaned the king's little house."
The next day the servant went again to the boy but he was still sleeping; she sprayed water on his face but he didn't wake up.
Again she stayed there until evening.
She took the water home and the king's daughter asked her, "Why did you come late today, what are you hiding from me?"
"If you don't tell me the truth I will give you a hard time."
The servant told her the whole story unwillingly.
The next morning the servant and the king's daughter left the palace and went to the sycamore.
They climbed up and [saw] that a handsome young [boy] was sleeping there.
Upon seeing him the king's daughter started shaking. Then she sent the servant to bring water, dipped a flower in the water and hit the boy with the flower, [whereupon] he woke up.
The king's daughter asked him, "Who are you and what are you doing here?"
The young boy told her his whole story.
The king's daughter took him with her for several days. One day an old woman saw the boy in the daughter's palace.
She went and told the king.
The king sent his soldiers; they put the young man in prison and gave him a hard time.
His daughter cried a lot but couldn't do anything.
One night his daughter entered her father's treasure [room].
She stole gold and silver and that midnight she went to the prison guard.
She gave gold to him.
She took the boy from the prison and brought him home.
Time passed and the king became aware of the situation and ordered [his soldiers] to kill the young man.
The soldiers killed and buried him.
The [king's] daughter was very upset, didn't eat anything and didn't talk to anyone.
The servants went and told the situation to the king.
The king himself came to the girl and said, "Daughter, why are you doing this? Eat, and I will find you a handsome and skilled young man."
His daughter didn't even listen to him.

Some time passed, and the girl stole gold and silver from her father again, then she ordered the servants, "Tell my father that I want to go for a walk with all of you in the garden; ask him to give me permission."
The king agreed because he loved his daughter very much.
They were walking in the garden and the girl threw the gold.
The servants grabbed [the gold] and started fighting.
The girl ran away from there, nobody saw her.
She went to the boy's grave and [saw] that two flowers had grown there.
One was half dead and the other was beautiful.
The girl cried and said, "Oh God, why is this flower half dead?"
A sound came out from the grave, "The half dead [flower] is me and the beautiful one is you".
Then the grave opened wide, the girl entered the boy's grave, and then it closed again.
The servants saw that the king's daughter was not there; they looked for her everywhere but couldn't find her.
The king became aware of this and he sent all his soldiers to look for her.
But nobody found her.
The king had a smart vizier, who said, "The girl is lost because of that boy."
"Maybe she entered his grave."
They went and checked the grave [and saw] that it was closed like that.
The vizier said, "Open the grave."
They opened the grave and saw the two [lovers] embracing each other in death.
The king ordered [them] to bury his daughter separately.
They separated the dead bodies from each other, and buried the girl in another place.
After some time, two sycamores grew from their graves, and their branches wrapped around each other.
They told the king about it and he ordered [them] to cut the sycamores.
At that moment the sycamores turned into two doves and flew away.
They flew for a while and reached Kingir's hometown and turned into humans.
Kingir asked, "Who is the king of this region?".
People replied, "We had a great king, but he became blind because he lost his son."
"Now someone else is ruling [the region]."
Kingir came to his father and said, "Oh king, what happened to you?"
[The old king] replied, "My dear son, only God knows of my condition".
"I have been burning [with grief] because of my dear Kingir."
He [Kingir] asked, "If your son came now, would you still recognize him?"
His father replied, "Your voice is similar to [his voice] but my eyes cannot see, that I might look at you".
Kingir rubbed his sleeve on [his father's] face.
He was able to see.
Then they hugged each other and both cried.
Then again they became young like before.
He [the king] held on his son's neck and cried a lot.
After that, he celebrated for seven days.
Kingir and the girl did nikah and [his father] made him the king instead of him.
Nikah is an Islamic wedding ceremony.
Then they lived happy and cheerfully.
